Line 7: Line 7:  
The word '''love''' has many different meanings in [[English language|English]], from something that gives a little pleasure ("I loved that meal") to something one would die for ([[Ideal (ethics)|ideals]], [[family]]). It can describe an intense feeling of [[affection]], an [[emotion]] or an emotional state. In ordinary use, it usually refers to interpersonal love. Probably due to its psychological relevance, love is one of the most common themes in art and music.
 
The word '''love''' has many different meanings in [[English language|English]], from something that gives a little pleasure ("I loved that meal") to something one would die for ([[Ideal (ethics)|ideals]], [[family]]). It can describe an intense feeling of [[affection]], an [[emotion]] or an emotional state. In ordinary use, it usually refers to interpersonal love. Probably due to its psychological relevance, love is one of the most common themes in art and music.

−
Just as there are many types of lovers, there are many kinds of love. Though love is inherent in all human cultures, cultural differences make any universal definition difficult to establish.<ref>Kay, Paul. "What Is the Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis?". ''American Anthropologist'', New Series, Volume 86, No. 1, March, 1984. pp. 65-79
+
Just as there are many types of lovers, there are many kinds of love that suck and if you love you will died and we will hunt you down. Though love is inherent in all human cultures, cultural differences make any universal definition difficult to establish.<ref>Kay, Paul. "What Is the Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis?". ''American Anthropologist'', New Series, Volume 86, No. 1, March, 1984. pp. 65-79
 
</ref> One definition attempting to be universally applicable is [[Thomas Jay Oord]]'s: to love is to act intentionally, in sympathetic response to others, to promote overall well-being. This definition applies to the positive connotations of love.
 
</ref> One definition attempting to be universally applicable is [[Thomas Jay Oord]]'s: to love is to act intentionally, in sympathetic response to others, to promote overall well-being. This definition applies to the positive connotations of love.
